biography.value:
Prince of Demons, the Sibilant Beast, and Master of the Spiraling Depths, Demogorgon is the embodiment of chaos, confusion, and destruction, seeking to corrupt all that is good and undermine order in the multiverse, to see everything dragged howling into the infinite depths of the Abyss.

The demon lord is a meld of different forms. He has a saurian lower body and clawed, webbed feet; suckered tentacles sprout from the shoulders of his great apelike torso, which is surmounted by two hideous simian heads named Aameul and Hathradiah. Their gaze brings bewilderment and confusion to any who confront them.

Similarly, the spiraling Y sign of Demogorgon’s cult drives those who contemplate it for too long to delirium. As a result, all followers of the Prince of Demons break with reality sooner or later.

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Demogorgon makes two Tentacle attacks. He can replace one attack with a use of Gaze.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Melee Weapon Attack: +17 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage 3d12 + @mod type=force average=true]] damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a [[/save con 23 format=long]], or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if its hit point maximum is reduced to 0.

The [[lookup @name]] attacks with its [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Demogorgon turns his magical gaze toward one creature he can see within 120 feet of him. The target must succeed on a [[/save wis 23 format=long]] or suffer one of the following effects (choose one or roll a d6):

1–2: Beguiling Gaze. The target is &Reference[stunned]{stunned} until the start of Demogorgon’s next turn or until Demogorgon is no longer within &Reference[line]{line} of sight.

3–4: Confusing Gaze. The target suffers the effect of the confusion spell without making a saving throw. The effect lasts until the start of Demogorgon’s next turn. Demogorgon doesn’t need to concentrate on the spell.

5–6: Hypnotic Gaze. The target is &Reference[charmed]{charmed} by Demogorgon until the start of Demogorgon’s next turn. Demogorgon chooses how the &Reference[charmed]{charmed} target uses its action, reaction, and movement.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]] and a save is required.

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Demogorgon casts one of the following spells, requiring no &Reference[material]{material} components and using &Reference[cha]{Charisma} as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 23):

At will: detect magic, major image

3/day each: dispel magic, fear, telekinesis

1/day each: feeblemind, project image

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Lair Actions

On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Demogorgon can take one of the following lair actions; he can’t take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

Darkness. Demogorgon casts the darkness spell four times, targeting different areas with the spell. Demogorgon doesn’t need to concentrate on the spells, which end on initiative count 20 of the next round.

Illusory Duplicate. Demogorgon creates an illusory duplicate of himself, which appears in his space and lasts until initiative count 20 of the next round. On his turn, Demogorgon can move the illusory duplicate a distance equal to his walking speed (no action required). The first time a creature or an object interacts physically with Demogorgon (for example, by hitting him with an attack), there is a 50 percent chance that the illusory duplicate is affected, not Demogorgon, in which case the &Reference[ill]{illusion} disappears.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Regional Effects

The region containing Demogorgon’s lair is warped by his magic, creating one or more of the following effects:

Beguiling Realm. Within 6 miles of the lair, all &Reference[cha]{Charisma} (&Reference[per]{Persuasion}) and &Reference[cha]{Charisma} (&Reference[prf]{Performance}) checks have disadvantage, and all &Reference[cha]{Charisma} (&Reference[dec]{Deception}) and &Reference[cha]{Charisma} (&Reference[itm]{Intimidation}) checks have advantage.

Frenzied Animals. Beasts within 1 mile of the lair become frenzied and violent—even creatures that are normally docile. Within that area, any ability check involving &Reference[ani]{Animal Handling} has disadvantage.

Venomous Beasts. The area within 6 miles of the lair becomes overpopulated with poisonous snake;poisonous snakes and other venomous Beasts.

If Demogorgon dies, these effects fade over the course of 1d10 days.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Demogorgon’s Lair

Demogorgon makes his lair in a palace called Abysm, found on a layer of the Abyss known as the Gaping Maw. Demogorgon’s lair is a place of confusion and duality; the portion of the palace that lies above water takes the form of two serpentine towers, each crowned by a skull-shaped minaret. There, Demogorgon’s heads contemplate the mysteries of the arcane while arguing about how best to obliterate their rivals. The bulk of this palace extends deep underwater, in chill and darkened caverns.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Cultists of Demogorgon

Demogorgon’s followers are typically lone killers driven by the whispering voice of their master. His most blessed followers gain the Two Minds of Chaos trait.

Two Minds of Chaos. This creature has advantage on all &Reference[int]{Intelligence}, &Reference[wis]{Wisdom}, and &Reference[cha]{Charisma} saving throws.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Demogorgon turns his magical gaze toward one creature he can see within 120 feet of him. The target must succeed on a [[/save wis 23 format=long]] or suffer one of the following effects (choose one or roll a d6):

1–2: Beguiling Gaze. The target is &Reference[stunned]{stunned} until the start of Demogorgon’s next turn or until Demogorgon is no longer within &Reference[line]{line} of sight.

3–4: Confusing Gaze. The target suffers the effect of the confusion spell without making a saving throw. The effect lasts until the start of Demogorgon’s next turn. Demogorgon doesn’t need to concentrate on the spell.

5–6: Hypnotic Gaze. The target is &Reference[charmed]{charmed} by Demogorgon until the start of Demogorgon’s next turn. Demogorgon chooses how the &Reference[charmed]{charmed} target uses its action, reaction, and movement.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]] and a save is required.

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Demogorgon can take 2 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Demogorgon regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

Gaze. Demogorgon uses Gaze and must use either Beguiling Gaze or Confusing Gaze.

Tail. +17 to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage 2d10 + 9 type=bludgeoning average=true]] damage plus [[/damage 2d10 type=necrotic average=true]] damage.

Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions). Demogorgon uses Spellcasting.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

+17 to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage 2d10 + 9 type=bludgeoning average=true]] damage plus [[/damage 2d10 type=necrotic average=true]] damage.

description.value:
Legendary Resistance (3/Day). If Demogorgon fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Magic Resistance. Demogorgon has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
Two Heads. Demogorgon has advantage on saving throws against being &Reference[blinded]{blinded}, &Reference[deafened]{deafened}, &Reference[stunned]{stunned}, or knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious}.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

source.book: Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse

description.value:
For the duration, you sense the presence of magic within 30 feet of you. If you sense magic in this way, you can use your action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears magic, and you learn its school of magic, if any.

The spell can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.

source.book: Player’s Handbook

description.value:
You create the image of an object, a creature, or some other visible phenomenon that is no larger than a 20-foot &Reference[cube]{cube}. The image appears at a spot that you can see within range and lasts for the duration. It seems completely real, including sounds, smells, and temperature appropriate to the thing depicted. You can't create sufficient heat or &Reference[cold]{cold} to cause damage, a sound loud enough to deal &Reference[thunder]{thunder} damage or deafen a creature, or a smell that might sicken a creature (like a troglodyte's stench).

As long as you are within range of the &Reference[ill]{illusion}, you can use your action to cause the image to move to any other spot within range. As the image changes location, you can alter its appearance so that its movements appear natural for the image. For example, if you create an image of a creature and move it, you can alter the image so that it appears to be walking. Similarly, you can cause the &Reference[ill]{illusion} to make different sounds at different times, even making it carry on a conversation, for example.

Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an &Reference[ill]{illusion}, because things can pass through it. A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine that it is an &Reference[ill]{illusion} with a successful &Reference[int]{Intelligence} (&Reference[inv]{Investigation}) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the &Reference[ill]{illusion} for what it is, the creature can see through the image, and its other sensory qualities become faint to the creature.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the spell lasts until dispelled, without requiring your &Reference[concentration]{concentration}.

source.book: Player’s Handbook

description.value:
Choose one creature, object, or magical effect within range. Any spell of 3rd level or lower on the target ends. For each spell of 4th level or higher on the target, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. On a successful check, the spell ends.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you automatically end the effects of a spell on the target if the spell's level is equal to or less than the level of the spell slot you used.

source.book: Player’s Handbook

description.value:
You project a phantasmal image of a creature’s worst fears. Each creature in a 30-foot &Reference[cone]{cone} must succeed on a &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} saving throw or drop whatever it is holding and become &Reference[frightened]{frightened} for the duration.

While &Reference[frightened]{frightened} by this spell, a creature must take the Dash action and move away from you by the safest available route on each of its turns, unless there is nowhere to move. If the creature ends its turn in a location where it doesn’t have &Reference[line]{line} of sight to you, the creature can make a &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} saving throw. On a successful save, the spell ends for that creature.

source.book: Player’s Handbook

description.value:
You gain the ability to move or manipulate creatures or objects by thought. When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can exert your will on one creature or object that you can see within range, causing the appropriate effect below. You can affect the same target round after round, or choose a new one at any time. If you switch targets, the prior target is no longer affected by the spell.

Creature. You can try to move a Huge or smaller creature. Make an ability check with your spellcasting ability contested by the creature's &Reference[str]{Strength} check. If you win the contest, you move the creature up to 30 feet in any direction, including upward but not beyond the range of this spell. Until the end of your next turn, the creature is &Reference[restrained]{restrained} in your telekinetic grip. A creature lifted upward is suspended in mid-air.

On subsequent rounds, you can use your action to attempt to maintain your telekinetic grip on the creature by repeating the contest.

Object. You can try to move an object that weighs up to 1,000 pounds. If the object isn't being worn or carried, you automatically move it up to 30 feet in any direction, but not beyond the range of this spell.

If the object is worn or carried by a creature, you must make an ability check with your spellcasting ability contested by that creature's &Reference[str]{Strength} check. If you succeed, you pull the object away from that creature and can move it up to 30 feet in any direction but not beyond the range of this spell.

You can exert fine control on objects with your telekinetic grip, such as manipulating a simple tool, opening a door or a container, stowing or retrieving an item from an open container, or pouring the contents from a vial.

source.book: Player’s Handbook

description.value:
You blast the mind of a creature that you can see within range, attempting to shatter its intellect and personality. The target takes 4d6 &Reference[psychic]{psychic} damage and must make an &Reference[int]{Intelligence} saving throw.

On a failed save, the creature's &Reference[int]{Intelligence} and &Reference[cha]{Charisma} scores become 1. The creature can't cast spells, activate magic items, understand language, or communicate in any intelligible way. The creature can, however, identify its friends, follow them, and even protect them.

At the end of every 30 days, the creature can repeat its saving throw against this spell. If it succeeds on its saving throw, the spell ends.

The spell can also be ended by greater restoration, heal, or wish.

source.book: Player’s Handbook

description.value:
You create an illusory copy of yourself that lasts for the duration. The copy can appear at any location within range that you have seen before, regardless of intervening obstacles. The &Reference[ill]{illusion} looks and sounds like you but is intangible. If the &Reference[ill]{illusion} takes any damage, it disappears, and the spell ends.

You can use your action to move this &Reference[ill]{illusion} up to twice your speed, and make it gesture, speak, and behave in whatever way you choose. It mimics your mannerisms perfectly.

You can see through its eyes and hear through its ears as if you were in its space. On your turn as a bonus action, you can switch from using its senses to using your own, or back again. While you are using its senses, you are &Reference[blinded]{blinded} and &Reference[deafened]{deafened} in regard to your own surroundings.

Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an &Reference[ill]{illusion}, because things can pass through it. A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine that it is an &Reference[ill]{illusion} with a successful &Reference[int]{Intelligence} (&Reference[inv]{Investigation}) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the &Reference[ill]{illusion} for what it is, the creature can see through the image, and any noise it makes sounds hollow to the creature.

source.book: Player’s Handbook
